Nineteen years ago today, at 8:46 a.m. EST, American Airlines Flight 11 hit the north tower of the World Trade Center in New York City, beginning many months of nightmare, tragedy, heartbreak, and unimaginable suffering.

Later - we were reminded of the indomitable spirit of American strength, courage, hope, and love.

“If we learn nothing else from this tragedy, we learn that life is short and there is no time for hate.” — Sandy Dahl, wife of Flight 93 pilot Jason Dahl.

We remember.

We did it. It was not the first day of school we would have chosen, but it was the first day of school 2020 nonetheless. Today was filled with happy and sad tears, frustration and triumph, and so, so many smiles, "virtual" hugs, and high-fives.

The first day of school is so much more than new shoes and labeled lunch boxes. It's about possibilities, finding joy in learning, and opportunities to grow. This first day of school is no different. Seeing the faces of our students today, so ready for this new school year - we KNOW we will do amazing things together.

Happy first day of school, Central Bucks. If you'd like to share your "first day" pictures, we'd love to see them!

Our outstanding CBSD teachers and support staff returned this week for orientations, professional development, and conversation focused on preparing for a "back to school" unlike any other.

They took part in sessions designed to build comfort and confidence with curriculum, technology, and best practices in teaching and learning - both virtual and in-person.

These conversations were focused on reaching students, ensuring they feel heard, and building relationships with a focus on equity and inclusion - and meeting the needs of ALL learners.

A most sincere thank you goes out to all those who took time to visit our campuses and welcome our amazing faculty and staff back with messages of hope, love, and encouragement - either in person or by chalking our walks! Thank you to FEMO and other support staff for their hard work and dedication in preparing our schools to welcome back our amazing faculty and staff! We are #CBSDPROUD!

Our Friday "Story of Strength" is focused on 2019 CB East graduate, Neel Mehta. Along with some friends, Neel (currently studying applied mathematics, statistics, and computer science at Johns Hopkins University) created an app that tracks the COVID-19 virus with the hopes of using analytics to prevent transmission.

Called "Covetrace," this mobile application is designed with colleges and universities in mind, in order to provide them with an accurate and cost-effective solution to contact trace those who test positive for COVID-19.

We could not be more #CBSDPROUD of our brilliant alumni, leaders who are dedicated to making a difference in their world. Each week, Central Bucks families who are in need of some additional support with food during this pandemic crisis are invited to visit a weekly CBSD Farmers Market at Barclay Elementary School.

Organized and run by adminstrators and other Central Bucks staff, the event supports hundreds of families through the distribution of thousands of pounds of food weekly. The video below shared more information about all those who have supported this community effort - an embodiment of our CB Strength!

If you would like to be a part of this effort, you can conduct a food drive (details at www.cbsd.org/fooddrive), or make a monetary contribution to The Friends of John Barclay GoFundMe at www.cbsd.org/barclaygofundme.

On this School Nurse's Day, we are reminded that as we consider the enormous contributions of our front-line workers amid this national crisis, our school nurses have always been our students' "first line" of support.

Our nurses help us meet families' needs, connect them with critical resources, and counsel them on their children's health and wellness. They administer critical first aid and daily medical support for all students, monitor medically fragile students, and the health of our building faculty and staff. Our nurses do all this and more...with hugs!

Join us in saluting our school nurses, whose compassionate approach to care sits at the heart of our schools. #CBSDPROUD #CBStrong

This week's story of strength focuses on our teachers! It goes without saying that Central Bucks teachers pursued a career in education because they are dedicated to learning - and they love students!

As we consider the social and emotional wellness challenges brought about by this crisis - the significant loss of personal interaction with those we care about is one of the greatest sacrifices we have had to make. Our teachers are no exception! They miss their colleagues, but most of all - they miss all of you. When check-ins and other opportunities to meet virtually aren't enough - our amazing Central Bucks teachers have been "sneaking" around to show their students just how missed and loved they are! We've featured just two examples (of many!) below...Dr. Lang of CB South, and Mrs. Barno of Buckingham Elementary School! Remember to share your story of strength with Angela Linch at alinch@cbsd.org. #CBSDPROUD #CBStrong

Day one of distance learning has come to a close. Today was filled with triumphs, connections, challenges, tears, laughter, celebration, and so much more. Our students and teachers worked together with help from families through extraordinary and unprecedented times.

Older siblings helped younger ones navigate technology and solve problems. Preschool students proudly sat alongside older brothers and sisters as they watched their teachers read them books live.

Tech support was delivered drive-through style. Principals, counselors, and administrators planned and communicated and calmed concerns.

Our students helped around the house, shared hugs, and miles of smiles. They connected with their teachers and their fellow students. Pajamas were worn well into the day, and many, many snacks were consumed.

Our community reached out to help one another and offers of support were shared neighbor to neighbor. It wasn't a day without its share of challenge - but it was a day no one among us will soon forget.

Thank you for your strength, Central Bucks. Together, we can do anything.

The students enjoyed time at both the Bucks County Courthouse and the Justice Center, and had lunch courtesy of the commissioners.

CB South Teacher Frank Woodring is being awarded the VFW Teacher of the Year Award for Pennsylvania for the 2019-2020 school year! Mr. Woodring is now a candidate for the Smart/Maher VFW National Citizenship Education Teacher Award. This award recognizes exceptional teachers for their outstanding commitment to teaching Americanism and patriotism to their students.

Mr. Woodring is a US Navy Veteran and the advisor for the Operation Eternal Gratitude (OEG) club at CB South, which is a military support club that sends care package overseas to deployed troops. Last school year, the club sent over 11,000 pounds of items to various locations. In addition, Mr. Woodring helped create South’s Wall of Honor, which recognizes former CB South students who have served in different military roles after graduation. He also oversees the students in the Veterans Day committee who organize a meaningful annual Veterans Day ceremony at the school.

National History Day® (NHD) has selected CB West teacher Brian Weaver as one of only ten master teachers who will create a valuable new classroom resource. This guide will be the newest addition to the wealth of materials provided by the Library of Congress Teaching with Primary Sources Consortium for educators in the United States and around the globe.

Over the next several months, Mr. Weaver and the cohort of master teachers will work directly with NHD and Library of Congress staff to create and test this new guide which will present the processes for successful student research and the formation of strong, cogent historical arguments. In its lesson plans for practical application, the guidebook will feature primary sources from the vast collections of the Library of Congress, the largest library in the world. Mr. Weaver’s experience will include travel to the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C., for advanced training and on-site writing and development workshops. Read all about this "master teacher" at https://tinyurl.com/wunycmm

Research shows that women are more likely to pursue computer science if they are given the opportunity to explore it in high school. Central Bucks High School West is proud to be a recipient of The College Board's Female Diversity Award for AP Computer Science Principles! Schools honored with the AP Computer Science Female Diversity Award have expanded young women’s access to AP computer science courses.

Out of the 20,000 institutions that offer AP courses, 818 achieved this important result during the 2018-2019 school year--nearly 20% more than the 685 schools recognized last year. In 2019, CB West was one of 639 recognized in the category of AP Computer Science Principles.

Middle Bucks Institute of Technology students enrolled in the Automotive Technology and Collision Repair Technology
programs sponsored a fundraiser to benefit the Auto Dealers CARing for Kids Foundation’s Driving Away the Cold
program. The Driving Away the Cold initiative was established by the automotive industry in 2008 and provides new
coats to underprivileged children who would otherwise not have them.

The Middle Bucks Automotive Technology and Collision Repair Technology students put their own spin on this worthy
fundraiser by building a unique collection container from a car engine and calling their campaign “Change for Change” to
encourage fellow students to donate their extra change. Their hard work paid off because the students collected $1,288,
which was donated to the Auto Dealers CARing for Kids Foundation’s Driving Away the Cold program.

Holicong Middle School Student Mason Matich was honored as one of the brightest students in the world at an international Johns Hopkins Center for Talented Youth (CTY) awards ceremony.

Mason was honored for his exceptional performance on the ACT. More than 18,000 grade two through eight students representing all 50 states and more than 80 countries tested through CTY’s Talent Search - about 2,100 students from this group who scored in the top 12 percent on their test were invited to attend the Grand Ceremony, held at Johns Hopkins University.

“Honorees, today we celebrate the knowledge and perseverance you have demonstrated by taking a test designed for much older students, and achieving a remarkably high score,” said Amy Shelton, CTY’s Interim Executive Director and Director of Research. “Above all, today we celebrate your potential. In the months and years to come, we hope you’ll stay curious, keep challenging yourself, and continue learning and growing as a scholar. Use your talents to do good things in your communities.”

Congratulations, Mason! We're #CBSDPROUD of you!

Titus Elementary School second grade student Anisha Cheruvu is in the spotlight!

Anisha Cheruvu bubbles over with positive energy. The Titus Elementary School second grader, who took regular “giggle breaks” during her interview, would make anyone smile who had the joy to be in her presence.

Anisha is also an accomplished dancer, who has trained in both “Bollywood” and classical “Kuchipudi” dance styles.

Anisha practices – a lot. “I have class with my teacher at her house with my dance friends on Tuesdays and Thursdays,” she explains, “It’s more than an hour, but if we’re preparing for a show, it’s even longer!”

When asked why she dances, her answer is simple. “I like doing it and I put my heart in it!”

Currently learning a new song, Anisha explains why this activity brings her so much happiness. “Not very many people do this kind of dancing,” she said, “It’s a privilege to do this, and so it’s kind of special.”

#CBSDPROUD of you, Anisha! See a video of Anisha dancing and read more about this inspiring CBSD student at https://tinyurl.com/y6ek7cz8

CB East teachers Amanda Prothero and Vanessa Power welcomed Congressman Brian Fitzpatrick to their 11th grade American government classes for a 90-minute question and answer session.

The students were briefed on Rep. Fitzpatrick’s background as an FBI agent and his current role and perspectives on service in the United States Congress. Students asked questions on various topics important to them, including the current impeachment inquiry, gun control, gerrymandering, healthcare, education, and more.

Rep. Fitzpatrick relayed that he was both exhausted and impressed with the students' questions! Students felt the experience was both valuable and helpful in understanding more about the nation's government and political landscape.

Central Bucks students, 75 from Central Bucks High School West and 75 from Lenape Middle School, participated in the Feed My Starving Children event at Delaware Valley University.

Teams of students hand packed meals that will be distributed to children around the world by Feed My Starving Children®, a nonprofit committed to feeding starving children. Their approach is to have children and adults pack meals specifically formulated for undernourished children and ship these meals to distribution partners around the world.

Central Bucks student Paige Sokolis was instrumental in organizing the event while a ninth-grade student at Lenape, and organized the event again this year at Central Bucks High School West.

The students worked alongside hundreds of other volunteers to pack tens of thousands of stable, shelf-ready meals of soy, rice, dehydrated vegetables and vitamins.

Central Bucks High School South was honored to induct the 2019 inaugural class to the Central Bucks High School South Hall of Fame. They are: Josh Adams, CB South Class of 2015 (football and spring track and field), Colleen Christian Ruggear, CB South Class of 2007 (basketball and spring track), Dong Kim, CB South Class of 2005 (swimming), Tom Mallon, CB South Class of 2010 (cross country, winter and spring track), and the Central Bucks South 2012 PIAA AAAA State Champion Softball Team.

School Board President Glenn Schloeffel, and directors Jodi Schwartz and Tracy Suits were on hand to present plaques to the inductees during the CB South homecoming game. Pennsylvania State Representative Todd Polinchock was also in attendance and presented certificates of honor to each inductee.

The CB South Hall of Fame was created to recognize and honor former students, athletes, educators, administrators, coaches, teams, community members, and staff for their outstanding achievements and contributions to the Central Bucks High School South community.

This morning at approximately 10:05 a.m., individuals within the building reported an odor of gas within the C-wing at Central Bucks East High School. Emergency response procedures were immediately initiated. Students and staff were evacuated from the building and local emergency response officials were contacted.

Local fire and police responded within minutes, and following an investigation, determined that the source of the odor was a science classroom. Those lines have been closed, and CBSD Facilities and Energy Management Operations personnel are on site to investigate necessary repairs.

The fire marshal has determined that the building is safe to reoccupy, and authorized that students and staff return to the building. CB East has resumed normal operations, and we thank our students, faculty, and staff for their calm, organized evacuation.

We appreciate the patience and support of our families as we focused on the safety of our students before issuing this information to the community.

Tamanend Middle School teachers, staff, and Principal Brian Caugie assembled meals for families throughout the county at the United Way of Bucks County's "Knock Out Hunger" event at Bucks County Community College. The United Way reports that 9% of Bucks County residents don’t know where their next meal is coming from and 16% of all children in Bucks County are food insecure. "In a community like ours, no family should have to choose between food on the table and a roof over their heads," they said. As the Tamanend volunteer shift came to a close during this fun, upbeat event - more than 50,000 meals had been packaged! #CBSDPROUD
